Line 53: Line 53:
The basic salaries at Google are considered low by some. For instance, [[system administrator]] earn no more than $33,000-37,000, which some argue to be pretty low especially by [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] standards.
The basic salaries at Google are considered low by some. For instance, [[system administrator]] earn no more than $33,000-37,000, which some argue to be pretty low especially by [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] standards.
  +   +   +   +
==Management==
  +

  +
*CEO: [[Eric E. Schmidt]], 49, $554.00K
  +
*CFO: [[George Reyes]], 50, ?
  +
*President of Technology: [[Sergey Brin]], 30, $370.00K
  +
*President of Products: Larry E. Page, 31, $367.00K
  +
*Sr. VP: [[Omid Kordestani]], 40, $572.00K
  +   +
==Analysts==
  +
[[Research analyst]] covering Google Inc. See also [http://finance.yahoo.com/q/sa?s=GOOG GOOG: Star Analysts for GOOGLE - Yahoo! Finance]
  +   +
*[[Tinker, John]] ([[Thinkequity Partners]])
  +

  +

  +
*[[Khan, Imran]] ([[J.P. Morgan Chase]])

*[[Terry, Heath]] ([[Credit Suisse First Boston]])
  +
*[[Wolk, Marianne]] ([[Susquehanna Financial Group]])
  +   +
==Corporate culture==
  +
===Philosophy===
  +
Google is known for its relaxed corporate culture, reminiscent of the [[Dot-com]] boom. Google's corporate philosophy is based on many casual principles including, "You can make money without doing evil", "You can be serious without a suit" and "work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun." A complete list of corporate fundamentals is available on Google's web site [http://www.google.com/corporate/tenthings.html]. The company encourages equality along the corporate levels and tells its employees to work on a personal project one day a week. Twice a week there is a [[roller hockey]] game in the company parking lot.
  +   +
===Googleplex===
  +
The [[Googleplex]]'s lobby (Google headquarters) is decorated with a piano, lava lamps and a real time projection of current search queries. The hallways are full of exercise balls and [[bicycle]]s. Each employee has a [[Linux]] workstation and access to the corporate recreation center. The recreation center includes a workout room with weights and rowing machines, locker rooms, washers and dryers, a massage room, assorted [[video game]]s, [[Foosball]], a [[piano|baby grand piano]], a pool table and [[ping pong]]. In addition to the [[Recreation room|rec room]], there are snack rooms stocked with various [[cereal]]s, [[gummy bear]]s, [[M&Ms]], [[toffee]], [[licorice]], [[cashew]]s, [[yoghurt|yogurt]], [[carrot]]s, fresh fruit, and dozens of different drinks including fresh [[juice]], [[soft drink|soda]] and make-your-own [[cappuccino]]. After eating, people can relieve themselves on digital toilets similar to [[Japanese toilets]].
  +   +
===IPO and culture===
  +
Many people have suggested that after Google's IPO their culture will not be able to stay so "fun" and focused on the future.[http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,63241,00.html?tw=wn_story_related] [http://www.ciol.com/content/news/2004/104043001.asp] The company may be required to answer to shareholders who will want the company to cut back on employee benefits and to focus on short term advances. Also, it may be hard to maintain a collegial atmosphere when some of the employees are paper-millionaires. In a report given to potential investors, co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page promised that the IPO would not change the company's culture. Later Mr. Page said, "We think a lot about how to maintain our culture and the fun elements."
==Criticism and controversy==
==Criticism and controversy==
Line 98: Line 128:
===The PageRank system===
===The PageRank system===
Google's central PageRank system has been criticized, some calling it "undemocratic". Common arguments are that the system is unfairly biased towards large web sites, and that the criteria for a page's importance are not subject to [[peer review]]. The system is also highly susceptible to manipulation and fraud through the use of dummy sites.
Google's central PageRank system has been criticized, some calling it "undemocratic". Common arguments are that the system is unfairly biased towards large web sites, and that the criteria for a page's importance are not subject to [[peer review]]. The system is also highly susceptible to manipulation and fraud through the use of dummy sites.

==Controversy and criticism==
  â
Like any large company, Google has been the subject of controversy and criticism, particularly for the way it runs its influential search engine. See the [[Google search#Criticism and controversy|Criticism and controversy]] section of the [[Google search]] article.
